is a rural town in the

value: directions=Rt 104A E past Sterling hamlet, follow brown signs

content=For seven weekends every summer, the village of Warwickshire emerges from 16th-century England to appear in rural Cayuga County.  Within you'll find all manner of traditional games, foods, rides, arts and crafts.  Meet interesting people from common washerwomen to the Queen herself, and enjoy special theme weekends like the Pirate Invasion and the Highland Fling.  This is the premier upstate Renaissance festival.

Sterling is a sleepy little town... except when the Renaissance Festival is going on. Even then, most visitors attend as a day trip from Oswego, Syracuse, or even Rochester. But if you do want to stay overnight, there are a surprising number of options for such a small community. Most of them are in Fair Haven, catering to Little Sodus Bay fishermen and boaters.

value: address=14424 West Bay Rd, Fair Haven

content=A variety of accommodations available, from RV sites to cottages to a B&B all to yourself... though for that last one they only accept weekly reservations.  Kitchen facilities available, and Wi-Fi throughout the resort.
price=$100-$150 per night, depending on duration of stay and season; add $25 for each guest beyond 6
content=This three-bedroom lodge is designed for large families or groups of fishermen looking to stay for multiple nights. A fully equipped kitchen makes such stays quite practical.

content=Most of the cottages and motels and B&Bs around Fair Haven are decades old, dating back to a time when the Bay was a popular summer resort getaway. The Fair Haven Motel, however, opened in 2007, so the amenities and decor are up-to-date.  A bit spartan, but up-to-date.  10 units each with A/C, refrigerator, microwave.
price=$89-$135; add $40 for each guest beyond 2; breakfast included
content=Four rooms available, each sharing a bath with another. Wi-Fi, refrigerators, cozy shared living room. Two night minimum.

content=Open since 1910, this is a venerable hotel with B&B-style accommodations. The food, by all accounts, is outstanding, and the hotel's restaurant is quite popular even among those not staying here. The rooms get more mixed reviews; some guests have found problems with upkeep and cleanliness, and the decor is seriously dated. The location is hard to beat, though, and some of the rooms have incredible views looking west over the bay. Closed winters.
content=Standard Bed and Breakfast with pretty good reviews.
address=14985 State Park Rd, Fair Haven
price=$15 plus fees, some minimum stay restrictions apply
content=The state park has 184 campsites as well as a 30 unit "cabin colony" with central bathroom facilities, and a handful of self-contained cottages with private facilities.
content=Whether you want sunny or wooded, bayfront or lakefront, this campground on the western promontory between Lake Ontario and Blind Sodus Bay offers quite a variety of camping sites.
address=14986 West Bay Rd, Fair Haven
price=$32-$60 for water and electric sites; $20 for tent sites; discounts for weekly and monthly reservations

content=Surrounded on three sides by water (Lake Ontario to the north, Blind Sodus Bay to the west, and Little Sodus Bay to the east), this campground has plenty of fishing and boating options nearby, as well as 1500 feet (450 m) of beach. Daily, weekly, and monthly rates.
